p: The study focuses on farmers in the state of Iowa, the top U.S. producer of corn and soybean ( U.S. Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service [USDA NASS], 2012). Climate change-related shifts in long-term weather patterns predicted for the state include warmer winters, longer growing seasons, higher dew point temperatures, higher annual stream flow, and more frequent extreme weather events ( Iowa Climate Change Impacts Committee [ICCIC], 2011). While changes such as a longer growing season may be favorable to Iowa agriculture, others could lead to negative impacts such as increased soil erosion, delays in planting or crop damage, higher incidence of pests and disease, and heat-induced pollination problems ( Hatfield et al., 2011; Rogovska & Cruse, 2011). Iowa has experienced many of these in recent years ( ICCIC, 2011), and thus represents a suitable context for research on farmer attitudes toward adaptation to such impacts.
